results.title: Crafts of My Province
results.creator_credit: Douglas Jackson, Kirk Jones, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film visit to New Brunswick craftsmen, such as the potters Kjeld and Erica Deichmann of Sussex, N.B., who demonstrate all stages, from potter’s wheel to kiln. Shown also are the hand-looming of woolens and the designing of jewelry from local stones and silver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Douglas Jackson, Kirk Jones, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Craft in the cowshed
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Jack S. Allan and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the correct method of milking cows to obtain the maximum yield of milk, and the importance of keeping the milking equipment clean.

results.title: The Cradle is rocking
results.creator_credit: Frank DeCola, Anthony Loem and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Traces the origins of jazz and depicts its continuing vitality in New Orleans, the city of its birth. Narrated by jazz musician, George Cola, it shows that jazz is still an expression of the daily joys and tribulations within the milieu from which it sprang many years ago. Cinematography by Tom Davenport.

results.title: The Cow tail switch: A folktale of Africa
results.creator_credit: Steven Clark, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: This animated folktale from the Liberian rain-forest recounts the death and return to life of the spirit to conquer death. Ogaloussa disappears and is forgotten by his family until a new son, Puli, in his first words asks for his father. A search yields Ogaloussa’s bones and his sons magically restore him to life. When Ogaloussa wants to give a beautiful cow tail switch to the son who did most to resuscitate him, he rewards Puli. For, the saying goes: “A man is not dead until he is forgotten”. The entire story is told by an African mother to her children. Adapted from the book “The Cow-Tail Switch” by Harold Courlander and George Herzog.

results.title: Cowes Regatta
results.brief_description: Hundreds of craft assemble in the harbour at Cowes, to participate in the world famous regatta. From Cowes the film takes you to the Brittania Cup race, 1965, with the Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne competing in the royal yacht, Bloodhound.

results.title: Cowboy
results.creator_credit: Gary Schlosser, Michael Ahnemann and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: The day-to-day existence of the working cowboy. It examines the life on a Californian ranch of a contemporary “cowpuncher”, Bill Bailey, and his family. Narrated by themselves, it reveals the hard work and simple pleasures and the profound rewards. Living in the open and close to the land, the cowboy retains the individuality and self-reliance which marked his forbears. Photographed at the Rex Ellsworth Ranch Tehachapi California.

results.title: Cow on the frontier = Krava na granici
results.brief_description: An animated film showing a harmless cow grazing a field, which unwittingly steps across the frontier that separates one country from another. A satire on war.

results.title: The Cow and the sprite
results.brief_description: One of a series of films which puppets are used to interpret folk legends. The film is an adaptation of an old Scotch-Irish folk story that tells of the happiness of man and of what it is composed.

results.title: The Cow and it's relatives
results.brief_description: The domestic cow and bull, and a very young calf are shown in their usual farm surroundings. The Indian humped cow, the zebu and the Yak of Tibet (also domesticated animals) the American bison or buffalo are shown; and finally, African antelopes of various kinds - the kudo, the nyala, the giant eland, the roan antelopes and the addax antelopes are presented briefly. The antelope is, biologically speaking, a close relative to the cow.

results.title: Covered Wagon
results.creator_credit: James Cruze and Famous Players-Lasky Corporation
results.brief_description: Recounts the journey by the men and women who left the Mississippi and Ohio valleys in 1848 to migrate to Oregon. Most of this Western epic was shot on location and captures the beauty of America’s vast frontier landscape. Essentially a romantic drama focusing on the leader of a wagon train who falls in love with the daughter of another wagon train leader. Before he can win her heart, he must clear himself of false cattle theft charges. During the journey, the wagon trains are exposed to forces of nature and the wrath of native Americans Indians defending their land against intruders. Script by Jack Cunningham based on the novel by Emerson Hough. Photographed by Karl Brown. Edited by Dorothy Arzner. Starring Alan Hale, J. Warren Kerrigan, Charles Ogle and Lois Wilson. Based on the novel by Emerson Hough.
